Issues.Title: Bulma hero does not play well for tabs within a box.
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma CSS bug**.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.4
My **browser** is: Firefox 107.0
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**

### Description

`tabs` within a `box` within a `hero-info` is not showing correctly. 


### Steps to Reproduce

Following is a CodePen to reproduce it: the top one is the default behaviour, the bottom one has some extra CSS.

https://codepen.io/AlexisTM/pen/abKEbXr

To overcome the issue, I added: 

```css
section.hero.is-info .tabs li.is-active a {
    color:#FFFFFF !important;
    background-color: #485fc7 !important;
}
```

The added section in front is to be prioritized against the following Bulma lines: (It was not `!important` at 0.7.4)

```css
.hero.is-info .tabs li.is-active a {
  color: #3e8ed0 !important;
  opacity: 1;
}
```

### Expected behavior

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6976744/202858355-cc92a5fa-f617-41aa-9c70-fd9c4cb8772f.png)


### Actual behavior

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6976744/202858339-5c006946-d852-48a4-8827-340b8a07f84f.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Bulma hero does not play well for tabs within a box." (#3593)

Issues.Title: Remove repetition of class name for native HTML elements
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
<!-- I'm using Bulma **version** [x.x.x] -->
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

I'd like to understand the **rationale** behind class names having the same name as tag names. As much as I like the aesthetics portrayed by the CSS framework, it is unclear as to why one would not prefer using the framework to markup the style just by using the native HTML tags, e.g. have `<button>XYZ</button>` instead of `<button class="button">XYZ</button>`. Similar logic follows for `<progress>`, `<input>`, etc.

### Expected behavior

It'd be preferable to have the markup directly applied to `<button>`, `<input>`, etc. tags rather than using the same tag names as class names. The only place where class names should include tag names is where one is supposed to be represented in the form of the other.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Remove repetition of class name for native HTML elements" (#3589)

Issues.Title: has-navbar-fixed-* works only on html/body

The class `has-navbar-fixed-top`/`has-navbar-fixed-bottom` can only be applied to the `<html>` or `<body>` element ([see docs](https://bulma.io/documentation/components/navbar/#fixed-navbar)). Unfortunately, Bulma doesn't provide that in this way.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.4
My **browser** is: Chromium

If the [definition in navbar.sass](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/master/sass/components/navbar.sass#L129-L134) would be a bit more extensive, meaning the restriction with `<html>` or `<body` would be removed, I could use the Bulma class as intended.

Issues.Title: Add an equivalent of Bootstrap's stretched links
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
It's a **feature request**.
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** [0.9.4]
My **browser** is: Firefox 104.0.1
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**

### Description

Currently, there's no class in Bulma that is a functional equivalent of [Bootstrap's stretched links](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/5.2/helpers/stretched-link/). In short, it's a class that, when applied to the `<a>` element, makes the entire containing block, such as cards, clickable as if it were part of the link. This not only improves code readability, but also makes the performed action more clear since it also highlights the `.stretched-link` element.

Currently, the closest alternative is to make the box an `<a>` element. While it does the job, it highlights the entire box, and putting any links inside it, like a button, breaks the whole thing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add an equivalent of Bootstrap's stretched links" (#3574)

Issues.Title: Media Query can fail on scaled displays
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
<!-- I'm using Bulma **version** [x.x.x] -->
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

<!-- Description of the bug, enhancement, or question -->
I found on a machine of mine that uses 125% display scaling with a 2560 x 1440 resolution if I snap a browser to 50% of the screen it ends up in a partial pixel width that is right between some of the `@media` queries. Even though you would think that with a calculation of 2560 / 1.25 * 0.50 = 1024 everything would be ok, the browser actually reports a width of 1023.20 pixels. 

Now this means that neither queries with `max-width: 1023px;` nor queries with `min-width: 1024px;` will take effect.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set display resolution to 2560 x 1440
2. Set display scale to 125%
3. Snap a browser window to either half of the screen
4. Try to open the nav menu on a site using the bulma CSS framework

### Expected behavior

<!-- What you expected to happen -->
The menu in tablet mode should open when I click the "hamburger" icon.

### Actual behavior

<!-- What actually happened -->
I noticed that when I tried to open the menu nothing happened. This is because the media query applies `display: block;` to items with `.navbar-menu.is-active`; however, none of the queries match due to partial pixels.

I am sure there are plenty more small issues that would occur due to this.

### Possible fix

I took some time and found that in **mixins.sass** I can replace lines such as `@media screen and (max-width: $device - 1px)` with `@media screen and (max-width: $device - 0.001px)`. The sass compiler does not seem to have any issue handling partial pixel values and browsers are ok with them as well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Media Query can fail on scaled displays" (#3572)

Issues.Title: Bulma Docs: Layout sub-items behave differently
Issues.Body:
Different sub-menu items under the **Layout** menu item on the left-hand side exhibit different behavior. In certain cases (e.g. 'hero' and 'container', at least), you see this behavior:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54010963/189462447-80cc839d-6b6a-4c5f-8dc6-64d82303342f.png)

Other menu items have the behavior I would expect, which is to say:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/54010963/189462484-87220de5-86c0-43a4-afd5-a0776884150e.png)

This is on `Firefox 104.0.2` and `Monterey 12.5.1` if that is at all helpful (although I suspect this is not platform/browser-specific as I can re-produce identical behavior in Safari).

Let me know if I can provide additional information.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Bulma Docs: Layout sub-items behave differently" (#3571)

Issues.Title: Problem on installing bulma
Issues.Body:
Im trying to install bulma with these instructions https://bulma.io/documentation/customize/with-node-sass/

When i run the npm run css-build i get this error

`{
  "status": 1,
  "file": "D:/bulma_tutorial/mybulma/sass/mystyles.scss",
  "line": 2,
  "column": 1,
  "message": "File to import not found or unreadable: mybulma/node_modules/bulma/bulma.sass.",
  "formatted": "Error: File to import not found or unreadable: mybulma/node_modules/bulma/bulma.sass.\n        on line 2 of sass/mystyles.scss\n>> @import \"mybulma/node_modules/bulma/bulma.sass\";\n   ^\n"
}`

i also tried to install with Sass CLI but i get the same error as well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Problem on installing bulma" (#3570)

Issues.Title: A proposal to change to a method of adjusting the gap with a CSS gap with a column layout
Issues.Body:
Due to the negative margin, a small scroll may occur on mobile.
Adjust it manually.
But the adjustment was very difficult.
We propose a method of using Flex + Gap normally.
